we that we build here so there is there's one pipeline for building the
prediction model which in the first stage pulls in the data from some base
data source does feature extraction and model training and then as the artifact
out of the stage we get the Train model and then usually this train model needs
to be converted or raft or containerized into some kind of more interoperable
interoperable model that is ready to be pulled into a serving layer and ready to

and then there is another pipeline which is the web application pipeline
and this obviously contains the code of the web application and then builds this
and the main artifact here is web applications are and that gets deployed
on a cloud server and when we blowing this this then holds in the latest
version of the prediction model and those two partners they are coupled
so whenever and you are changes made to
the web application we make sure it always puts in your latest prediction model but also importantly whenever
there's a change made to the data science code or the models we change
this should trigger the prediction model pipeline and then actually also trigger
the web application 5-9 to pull in the newest model and basically the final
goal here where we wanted to get because this is the state where we always want to get at continuous delivery was that a
data scientist would push the change could even be a minor one and then it
just would trigger a retraining of the model and there would be enough
automatic quality gates that this new prediction model would automatically go
all the way into production and into the hands of users but actually implementing
this in a rigorous way was quite a bit harder than we anticipated and also it
was quite hard to convince the data scientists of adopting this approach as
it and there are several reasons for this so here are a few of the of the
challenges that we were faced with how to version control training data
training data is usually thousands of files very large so very different to
and then source code also the training data is large and also the prediction
models are actually too large to put them into get because this is not what
it is made for so you need to link to some external storage then another issue
that we had was that a model retraining would initially slow down the entire
continuous delivery server because of course it's quite a different workload to build a web application source code
or to retrain a prediction model then we
found that the data scientists things we wanted to evaluate quite often several solutions at the same time whereas we
from the developer site were usually propagating a trunk based development
and few branches so there was also a bit of a clash and then to make things even worse data scientists they want to use
analytics notebooks right like Jupiter and stuff which is great for doing data science but which is very hard to
version control or at least it's fairly ugly and then how to actually unit test
data science code that is changed that is tied to changing data and it's also not as simple as just writing unit tests
or tests in general for for general software development code and then how
to prevent behavior changes of the model to break the application so those were a
lot of challenges that we were facing at the time so what are the reasons why
it's so hard to apply continuous delivery to machine learning applications because we were surprised
because we as I said we do this on pretty much every project for quite a

believe there are two main reasons for this to be very hard the one reason are
